text:
“Stay!” he yelled as Raskolnikov tried to leave. “Listen up. You’re all just a bunch of loud, fake idiots! When you have a problem, you just sit there stewing like a hen on an egg. And guess what? You’re not even original in that! There’s zero real life in you! You’re made of some weird ointment and have lymph instead of blood. I don’t trust any of you! You all act like you’re not even human! 

Stop!” he shouted again, seeing Raskolnikov move. “Hear me out! I’m having a housewarming tonight. They should be there by now, but I just popped in to get the guests. If you weren’t such a fool—a total fool—you’d come over tonight instead of wearing out your shoes out here! Since you’re out, I can’t help it! I’d hook you up with a comfy chair—my landlady has one—and a cup of tea, plus some company. Zossimov will be there too. So, will you come?”

“No.”

“Rubbish!” Razumihin shot back, losing his cool. “How do you know? You can’t even speak for yourself! You don’t know anything! I’ve fought with people a thousand times and always ended up going back to them. You feel ashamed and just go back! So remember, Potchinkov’s house on the third floor…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Razumihin passionately urges Raskolnikov to join him for a gathering, criticizing his isolation and lack of social engagement.
